snp3.10:1.1.comm: This discourse occurs in shorter, and presumably earlier, versions in the Sagāthāvagga (SN 6.10) and the Aṅguttara (AN 10.89). A Chinese parallel is included in DA 30.

snp3.10:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
snp3.10:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

snp3.10:1.3.pli: Atha kho kokāliko bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho kokāliko bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
snp3.10:1.3.eng: Then the mendicant Kokālika went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

snp3.10:1.4.pli: “pāpicchā, bhante, sāriputtamoggallānā, pāpikānaṃ icchānaṃ vasaṃ gatā”ti.
snp3.10:1.4.eng: “Sir, Sāriputta and Moggallāna have corrupt wishes. They’ve fallen under the sway of corrupt wishes.”

snp3.10:2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā kokālikaṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:
snp3.10:2.1.eng: When this was said, the Buddha said to Kokālika,

snp3.10:2.2.eng: “Don’t say that, Kokālika! Don’t say that, Kokālika!

snp3.10:2.3.eng: Have confidence in Sāriputta and Moggallāna,

snp3.10:3.2.pli: tatiyampi kho kokāliko bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
snp3.10:3.2.eng: For a third time Kokālika said to the Buddha,

snp3.10:3.3.pli: “kiñcāpi me, bhante, bhagavā saddhāyiko paccayiko, atha kho pāpicchāva sāriputtamoggallānā, pāpikānaṃ icchānaṃ vasaṃ gatā”ti.
snp3.10:3.3.eng: “Despite my faith and trust in the Buddha, Sāriputta and Moggallāna have corrupt wishes. They’ve fallen under the sway of corrupt wishes.”

snp3.10:3.4.pli: Tatiyampi kho bhagavā kokālikaṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:
snp3.10:3.4.eng: For a third time, the Buddha said to Kokālika,

snp3.10:3.5.eng: “Don’t say that, Kokālika! Don’t say that, Kokālika!

snp3.10:3.6.eng: Have confidence in Sāriputta and Moggallāna,

snp3.10:4.1.pli: Atha kho kokāliko bhikkhu uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
snp3.10:4.1.eng: Then Kokālika got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

snp3.10:4.2.pli: Acirappakkantassa ca kokālikassa bhikkhuno sāsapamattīhi piḷakāhi sabbo kāyo phuṭo ahosi;
snp3.10:4.2.eng: Not long after he left his body erupted with boils the size of mustard seeds.

snp3.10:4.3.pli: sāsapamattiyo hutvā muggamattiyo ahesuṃ; muggamattiyo hutvā kaḷāyamattiyo ahesuṃ; kaḷāyamattiyo hutvā kolaṭṭhimattiyo ahesuṃ; kolaṭṭhimattiyo hutvā kolamattiyo ahesuṃ; kolamattiyo hutvā āmalakamattiyo ahesuṃ; āmalakamattiyo hutvā beḷuvasalāṭukamattiyo ahesuṃ; beḷuvasalāṭukamattiyo hutvā billamattiyo ahesuṃ; billamattiyo hutvā pabhijjiṃsu; pubbañca lohitañca pagghariṃsu.
snp3.10:4.3.eng: The boils grew to the size of mung beans, then chickpeas, then jujube seeds, then jujubes, then myrobalans, then unripe wood-apples, then ripe wood-apples. Finally they burst open, and pus and blood oozed out.

snp3.10:4.4.pli: Atha kho kokāliko bhikkhu tenevābādhena kālamakāsi.
snp3.10:4.4.eng: Then the mendicant Kokālika died of that illness.

snp3.10:4.5.pli: Kālaṅkato ca kokāliko bhikkhu padumaṃ nirayaṃ upapajji sāriputtamoggallānesu cittaṃ āghātetvā.
snp3.10:4.5.eng: He was reborn in the Pink Lotus hell because of his resentment for Sāriputta and Moggallāna.
snp3.10:4.5.comm: This discourse gives no fewer than three independent ways of counting the duration of the Pink Lotus (paduma) hell, plus a simile, plus a commentary. The key to reconciling the three numbers is to consider them numerologically rather than mathematically: simple numbers convey the basic meaning, which is expanded by multiplication. All three methods yield 512 to various powers of ten. 512 breaks down to 500 (= a large number) plus 12 (= months of the year), with the sense, “a long period of time”. In one case, 12 expands to 36 (= months of the year in past, present, and future); numerologically, such variations are different expressions of the same idea. The exact quantity of the power of ten varies, but each is a multiple of the other by 10 million (a crore or koṭi or abbuda). The result conveys the sense, “a super-expanded long period of time”.

snp3.10:5.1.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho brahmā sahampati bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
snp3.10:5.1.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious divinity Sahampati, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,

snp3.10:5.2.eng: “Sir, the mendicant Kokālika has passed away.

snp3.10:5.3.pli: kālaṅkato ca, bhante, kokāliko bhikkhu padumaṃ nirayaṃ upapanno sāriputtamoggallānesu cittaṃ āghātetvā”ti.
snp3.10:5.3.eng: He was reborn in the Pink Lotus hell because of his resentment for Sāriputta and Moggallāna.”

snp3.10:5.4.eng: That’s what the divinity Sahampati said.

snp3.10:5.5.pli: idaṃ vatvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyi.
snp3.10:5.5.eng: Then he bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right side, before vanishing right there.

snp3.10:6.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassā rattiyā accayena bhikkhū āmantesi:
snp3.10:6.1.eng: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha told the mendicants all that had happened.

snp3.10:6.2.pli: “imaṃ, bhikkhave, rattiṃ brahmā sahampati abhikkantāya rattiyā …pe…

snp3.10:6.3.pli: idamavoca, bhikkhave, brahmā sahampati, idaṃ vatvā maṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyī”ti.

snp3.10:7.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
snp3.10:7.1.eng: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha,

snp3.10:7.2.pli: “kīvadīghaṃ nu kho, bhante, padume niraye āyuppamāṇan”ti?
snp3.10:7.2.eng: “Sir, how long is the lifespan in the Pink Lotus hell?”

snp3.10:7.4.pli: taṃ na sukaraṃ saṅkhātuṃ ettakāni vassāni iti vā ettakāni vassasatāni iti vā ettakāni vassasahassāni iti vā ettakāni vassasatasahassāni iti vā”ti.
snp3.10:7.4.eng: It’s not easy to calculate how many years, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of years it lasts.”

snp3.10:7.5.eng: “But sir, is it possible to give a simile?”

snp3.10:8.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsatikhāriko kosalako tilavāho; tato puriso vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena ekamekaṃ tilaṃ uddhareyya.
snp3.10:8.1.eng: “Suppose there was a Kosalan load of twenty packs of sesame seed. And at the end of every hundred years someone would remove a single seed from it.
snp3.10:8.1.comm: A sesame seed weighs about 0.002 grams (“Some Physical Properties of Sesame Seed”, T.Y. Tunde-Akintunde and B.O. Akintund). The “pack” (khāri, originally “donkey-load”) of the Arthaśāstra is about 150 kg (Olivelle King, Governance, and Law, appendix 2, pg. 458). Twenty packs would be 3 tons, which is reasonable for a “load” (vāha) drawn by a heavy bullock cart (Arthaśāsatra 2.19.33 reckons the vaha similarly at about 2 tons). This results in 1.5 billion seeds and 150 billion years. On the other hand, the Pali khāri is carried by a single person and must be closer to 20 kg (SN 3.11:2.1, SN 7.9:14.1, DN 3:2.4.7, Ud 6.2:2.1). That would make a “Kosalan load” of 400 kg, which is reasonable for a load drawn by a single horse. This results in 250 million seeds and 25 billion years. This number is interesting because it is similar to the modern cosmological estimate of the life of the Universe. Neither of these results, however, agrees very well with the other calculations in this Sutta. The correspondence is not in the result but the simple numbers: twenty packs each hundred years correspond to the twenty times ten of the hells.

snp3.10:8.2.pli: Khippataraṃ kho so bhikkhu vīsatikhāriko kosalako tilavāho iminā upakkamena parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya, na tveva eko abbudo nirayo.
snp3.10:8.2.eng: By this means the Kosalan load of twenty packs of sesame seed would run out faster than a single lifetime in the Abbuda hell.
snp3.10:8.2.comm: Different texts reckon the abbuda (Sanskrit arbuda) to different powers of ten. Most authorities, however, count it at 10 million, which must be the correct value here, as it ultimately yields the number 512 for the paduma. | Ten hells are listed in total, the names of which do not correspond with the 21 or 28 listed in Purāṇas, nor with the seven Jain hells, nor with the hells of MN 130. The commentary offers three explanations for the obscure names of these hells: they are numbers reflecting the duration spent in Avīci; or they are the cries uttered by those suffering there; or they are simply the cold hells.

snp3.10:8.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati abbudā nirayā evameko nirabbudo nirayo.
snp3.10:8.3.eng: Now, twenty lifetimes in the Abbuda hell equal one lifetime in the Nirabbuda hell.
snp3.10:8.3.comm: The Sanskrit nyarbuda (or nirbuda) is said, rather, to be ten times the arbuda. The expansion in a series of twenty is required to reach the final number of 512.

snp3.10:8.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati nirabbudā nirayā evameko ababo nirayo.
snp3.10:8.4.eng: Twenty lifetimes in the Nirabbuda hell equal one lifetime in the Ababa hell.
snp3.10:8.4.comm: These names appear to be nonsensical. the commentary says they are named for the laments of their victims. The parallel at DA 30:104 offers specific explanations for each, although the names sometimes differ from the Pali.

snp3.10:8.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati ababā nirayā evameko aṭaṭo nirayo.
snp3.10:8.5.eng: Twenty lifetimes in the Ababa hell equal one lifetime in the Aṭaṭa hell.

snp3.10:8.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati aṭaṭā nirayā evameko ahaho nirayo.
snp3.10:8.6.eng: Twenty lifetimes in the Aṭaṭa hell equal one lifetime in the Ahaha hell.

snp3.10:8.7.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati ahahā nirayā evameko kumudo nirayo.
snp3.10:8.7.eng: Twenty lifetimes in the Ahaha hell equal one lifetime in the Yellow Lotus hell.

snp3.10:8.8.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati kumudā nirayā evameko sogandhiko nirayo.
snp3.10:8.8.eng: Twenty lifetimes in the Yellow Lotus hell equal one lifetime in the Fragrant Water Lily hell.
snp3.10:8.8.comm: The sogandhika is variously identified as blue or white.

snp3.10:8.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati sogandhikā nirayā evameko uppalako nirayo.
snp3.10:8.9.eng: Twenty lifetimes in the Fragrant Water Lily hell equal one lifetime in the Blue Water Lily hell.

snp3.10:8.10.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati uppalakā nirayā evameko puṇḍarīko nirayo.
snp3.10:8.10.eng: Twenty lifetimes in the Blue Water Lily hell equal one lifetime in the White Lotus hell.

snp3.10:8.11.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati puṇḍarīkā nirayā evameko padumo nirayo.
snp3.10:8.11.eng: Twenty lifetimes in the White Lotus hell equal one lifetime in the Pink Lotus hell.
snp3.10:8.11.comm: By this calculation, the Pink Lotus lasts for 10⁷ ×  20⁹ = 5.12 × 10¹⁸ years. The commentary supplies its own method, based on a very large abbuda of 10⁴². Nonetheless, this still yields a number in the same series, simply raised to a higher power of ten, namely 5.12 × 10⁵³.

snp3.10:8.12.pli: Padumaṃ kho pana bhikkhu nirayaṃ kokāliko bhikkhu upapanno sāriputtamoggallānesu cittaṃ āghātetvā”ti.
snp3.10:8.12.eng: The mendicant Kokālika has been reborn in the Pink Lotus hell because of his resentment for Sāriputta and Moggallāna.”

snp3.10:8.13.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

snp3.10:8.14.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
snp3.10:8.14.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

snp3.10:9.2.eng: with an axe in their mouth.

snp3.10:9.3.eng: A fool cuts themselves with it

snp3.10:10.1.eng: When you praise someone worthy of criticism,

snp3.10:10.2.eng: or criticize someone worthy of praise,

snp3.10:10.3.eng: you choose a losing hand with your own mouth:

snp3.10:10.4.eng: you’ll never find happiness that way.

snp3.10:11.1.eng: A losing hand at dice is a trivial thing,

snp3.10:11.2.eng: if all you lose is your money

snp3.10:11.3.eng: and all you own, even yourself.

snp3.10:11.5.eng: is to hate the holy ones.

snp3.10:12.1.eng: For a hundred thousand times a hundred million,
snp3.10:12.1.comm: The commentary, followed by Bodhi and Norman, conjoins this line with the “thirty-six” of the next. But the expression is found in three other passages of the Sagāthāvagga, and in all three it stands as a separate line (SN 6.4:5.3, SN 1.32:14.3, SN 5.5:4.1). | Here, we take an abbuda as 10 million and a nirabbuda as a hundred million.

snp3.10:12.2.eng: times five hundred and thirty-six times <j>a thousand times ten million years
snp3.10:12.2.comm: Vanarata suggests that the “thousands” of the first line should be distributed to the second line as well (Bodhi, Numerical Discourses, note 626, p. 1678). This kind of distribution of terms is common in mathematics; for an example in Pali verse, see SN 6.6:5.1. Here, however, it provides a crucial key to interpretation and translation. But we need to go further: the singular “hundred” in the first line is distributed to the singulars 36 and 5 in the second, while the plural “thousands” is distributed to the plural abbudāni (“tens of millions”). Thus we read the distributed line here as chattiṁsati pañcasataṁ ca (five hundred plus thirty-six)  sahassānaṁ abbudāni (“of thousands, tens of millions”). The juxtaposed numbers are multiplied. The duration of the Pink Lotus then works out as (100,000 × 100,000,000) × (536 × 1000 × 10,000,000) = 5.36 × 10²⁵ years.

snp3.10:12.3.eng: a slanderer of noble ones goes to hell,

snp3.10:12.4.eng: having aimed bad words and thoughts at them.
snp3.10:12.4.comm: The parallels at SN 6.10 and AN 10.89 end here. The remainder was presumably added later.

snp3.10:13.2.eng: as does one who denies what they did.

snp3.10:13.3.eng: Both are equal in the hereafter,

snp3.10:14.1.eng: Whoever wrongs a man who has done no wrong,

snp3.10:14.2.eng: a pure man who has not a blemish,

snp3.10:14.3.eng: the evil backfires on the fool,

snp3.10:15.1.eng: One addicted to the way of greed,

snp3.10:16.1.comm: I can’t find any evidence to support the commentary’s gloss as “liar”. I assume it is shorthand for vebhūtiya which is a synonym of pesuṇiya (DN 30:2.21.2 and DN 28:11.2).

snp3.10:16.4.eng: quiet now, for you are bound for hell.
snp3.10:16.4.comm: I can’t find any explanation for the shift to direct address in second person here. Perhaps these verses were inserted from a separate source.

snp3.10:17.1.eng: You stir up dust, causing harm,
snp3.10:17.1.comm: Norman and Bodhi both accept commentary’s kilesarajaṁ attani pakkhipasi, but this seems too narrow; their deeds harmed others too.

snp3.10:17.2.eng: when you, sinner, malign the good.

snp3.10:17.4.eng: you’ll go to the pit for a long time.

snp3.10:18.1.eng: For no-one’s deeds are ever lost,

snp3.10:18.3.eng: In the next life that stupid sinner

snp3.10:19.1.eng: They approach the place of impalement,

snp3.10:19.2.eng: with its iron spikes, sharp blades, and iron stakes.

snp3.10:19.3.eng: Then there is the food, which appropriately,

snp3.10:19.4.eng: is like a red-hot iron ball.

snp3.10:20.1.eng: For the speakers speak not sweetly,
snp3.10:20.1.comm: Commentary says the hell-keepers are the subject here, hell-dwellers the subject of the next line. But this seems forced and unnecessary. Those going to hell are screaming, not uttering sweet words.

snp3.10:20.2.eng: they don’t hurry there, or find shelter.

snp3.10:20.3.eng: They lie upon a spread of coals,

snp3.10:20.4.eng: they enter a blazing mass of fire.
snp3.10:20.4.comm: Read aggini-samaṁ jalitaṁ, as at Snp 3.10:22.2 below.

snp3.10:21.2.eng: they strike them there with iron hammers.

snp3.10:21.4.eng: which spreads about them like a fog.

snp3.10:22.1.eng: Next they enter a copper pot,

snp3.10:22.3.eng: There they roast for a long time,

snp3.10:22.4.eng: writhing in the masses of fire.

snp3.10:23.2.eng: in a mixture of pus and blood.

snp3.10:23.4.eng: everything they touch there hurts them.

snp3.10:24.3.eng: There’s not even a shore to go to,

snp3.10:24.4.eng: for all around are the same kind of pots.

snp3.10:25.2.eng: so sharp they cut their body to pieces.

snp3.10:25.3.eng: Having grabbed the tongue with a hook,

snp3.10:25.4.eng: they stab it, slashing back and forth.

snp3.10:26.1.eng: Then they approach the impassable Vetaraṇī River,
snp3.10:26.1.comm: The Vetaraṇī (also at SN 1.33:10.3) is featured in the later literature of the Brahmins (eg. Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.26.22, Skanda Purāṇa 6.1.226.32) and Jains (Sūtrakṛtāṅga 1.5.1.8).

snp3.10:26.2.eng: with its sharp blades, its razor blades.

snp3.10:26.4.eng: the wicked who have done wicked deeds.

snp3.10:27.1.eng: There dogs all brown and spotted,

snp3.10:27.2.eng: and raven flocks, and greedy jackals

snp3.10:27.4.eng: while hawks and crows attack them.

snp3.10:28.1.eng: Hard, alas, is the life here

snp3.10:28.3.eng: That’s why for the rest of this life

snp3.10:28.4.eng: a person ought do their duty without fail.

snp3.10:29.1.eng: Experts have counted the loads of sesame
snp3.10:29.1.comm: The commentator says that these two verses are absent from the old “Great Commentary”, which was his main source.

snp3.10:29.2.eng: as compared to the Pink Lotus Hell.

snp3.10:29.3.eng: For there are five times ten thousand times ten million,
snp3.10:29.3.comm: Instead of the abbuda we have here the koṭi, which is a more regular mathematical term for the same quantity, 10 million. The nahuta is variously reckoned, but its only other early Pali appearance is for a crowd size at Kd 1:22.8.2, where it is reasonably reckoned by the commentary as 10,000.

snp3.10:29.4.eng: plus another twelve hundred times ten million years—
snp3.10:29.4.comm: The calculation here is (50,000 × 10,000,000) + (1200 × 10,000,000) = 5.12 × 10¹¹ years. Multiply this by ten million to equal the prose reckoning (Snp 3.10:8.11), and by another ten million to equal the previous verse reckoning (Snp 3.10:12.2).

snp3.10:30.1.eng: as painful as life is said to be in hell,

snp3.10:30.2.eng: that’s how long one must dwell there.

snp3.10:30.3.eng: That’s why, for those who are pure, well-behaved, <j>full of good qualities,

snp3.10:30.4.eng: one should always guard one’s speech and mind.”
